properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A band of very heavy snow continues to move eastward across areas north of the Capital region. This band of heavy snow will weaken and move out of the region late this afternoon. Total accumulations are expected to be 10 to 15 cm. Due to the nature of this snow, amounts may be highly variable. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-19T01:39:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-18T19:41:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1456416374.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. A Pacific storm will continue to produce heavy snow over the region tonight. Another 2 to 4 cm is expected tonight with the snow tapering off overnight. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Total snowfall: locally near 10 cm in snow squalls. Maximum wind gusts: 50 to 70 km/h. Locations: King's County P.E.I., Iles-de-la-Madeleine, and western Cape Breton. Time span: tonight and Thursday. Remarks: Snow squall activity is expected to develop this evening as cold northwesterly winds strengthen. Snow squalls and flurries will taper off from west to east through the day on Thursday. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-19T13:29:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-18T21:30:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1873915889.2020
Area: Îles-de-la-Madeleine
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. Snow continues across parts of northern Manitoba. The snow has been falling quite heavy through the day in a few localities. This afternoon, snow began to taper off throughout west-central Manitoba. The snow will continue to subside throughout east-central and extreme northern Manitoba this evening. Regions in central Manitoba may see some freezing drizzle after the snow departs. The freezing drizzle risk will diminish in the evening and through the overnight. Please refer to local forecasts for additional details on timing and snowfall amounts. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-19T07:59:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-18T21:18:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3372062129.2020
Area: Brochet, Tadoule Lake, Gillam, Shamattawa

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A band of very heavy snow will develop through central Alberta this evening. Visibility will be reduced in the heavy snow. The northern extent of the heavy snow is expected to be along Highway 16, this includes the city of Edmonton. Total snowfall amounts are expected to vary across the city with the heaviest amounts falling in the south. The snow will move eastwards into Saskatchewan Thursday afternoon. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Total snowfall: locally 10 to 15 cm in snow squalls. Locations: along the Burgeo Highway. Time span: overnight tonight through the day Thursday. Remarks: Flurries will become more frequent this evening, with areas of snow squall activity developing as cold westerly winds strengthen. Snow squalls are expected to occur inland, mainly affecting the Burgeo Highway, with just a few flurries along the south coast. Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow with just a few kilometres are common. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-11-19T11:18:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-18T19:19:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3340336955.2020
Area: Burgeo - Ramea

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A Pacific frontal system moving across northern BC is bringing heavy snow to the Fort Nelson region. Heavy snow will spread to Fort Nelson region this evening and continue through tonight. Snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 cm are expected in the Fort Nelson region before the snow tapers off on Wednesday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A Pacific storm is bringing heavy snow and strong winds to Pine Pass. Conditions should finally improve this morning as the storm system exits the region. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Drizzle Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Areas of freezing drizzle are expected or occurring. Freezing drizzle is currently being reported in Flin Flon and Thompson. The webcam at Flin Flon is showing a layer of glaze, indicating that the freezing drizzle is accumulating slightly. The freezing drizzle will end early this evening in Flin Flon and later this evening in Thompson. ### Freezing drizzle can produce thin, hard-to-detect layers of ice. Freezing drizzle advisories are issued when drizzle falling in sub-zero temperatures is expected to freeze on contact, and over time create icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-19T06:02:15-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A Pacific frontal system moving across northern BC is bringing snow to the Fort Nelson region. Snow has continued through the night, and the band of heavier snowfall will remain over the northern sections of the region this morning. Further snowfall amounts of 2 to 4 cm are expected in the Fort Nelson region before the snow eases to light snow late this morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-19T07:26:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-18T15:27:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3992914781.2020
